direction.raw_text: as Dave, followed by Arly and Juan, bursts in. His eyes go around the room quickly until he finds Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all look quickly toward the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as excited as a schoolboy) George Clews is in town. He's seen what you done to Bob and he's a- lookin' for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- from stagecoach office window. The center of the street is clear and men's heads are peering from doorways.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- group at window, looking into street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave turns and looks curiously at Rocklin, who frowns impatiently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The street is clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Dave irritably) Tell him I'll be out in the street in front of the saloon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dashing out, radiant) Uh-huh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The place is quite full and the atmosphere is one of expectancy despite the outward casualness of the patrons. A group lolls near the window, looking toward the stage office. At the door a couple of customers peer out over the swinging doors. The bar supports other customers engaged in various private conversations but all are mindful of the presence of George Clews who, with his brother, Bob, stands at the bar's center, morosely toying with a glass of whisky in front of him. He is quite conscious of the subtle glances of the others, but regards them all with disdain. He downs his drink, and speaks his thought to Bob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Old Dave appears in a high state of excitement, and halts with the swinging doors half open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George Clews turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George Clews frowns. His eye catches sight of a king-size glass of beer being slid across the bar to Shorty Davis, standing alongside him. That quick, Clews beats Shorty to the glass and hurls it at Dave, who ducks out. Cap, anticipating trouble, brings a sawed-off shotgun up from under the bar and now watches Clews and Shorty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Shorty can reply, Clews yanks his hat down over the little fellow's eyes, and gives him a backward shove that sends him sprawling into a corner where we leave him struggling to get his hat off. The crowd resents this, but doesn't dare do anything, except Cap, who holds his shotgun in sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George and Bob Clews are now a few steps from the bar. They have turned as Cap spoke and are looking at the shotgun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George turns and starts for the doors as Bob comes back to the bar to settle up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm gonna get his ears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (loudly) Hi you, George Clews --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rocklin says if you don't come out, he'll come in here after you, an' tear you apart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taps Clews) That was my beer, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nastily) If he comes in again -- I'll throw you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the Clews) That does it, boys -- you know where the door is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bob) Com-mon -- I'll get his ears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not until I get my money --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's three drinks and a broken beer glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Bob, after a second's deliberation) Pay 'im.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get his ears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: AS GEORGE CLEWS BURSTS OUT THROUGH THE DOORS PAP

direction.raw_text: - AS GEORGE CLEWS BURSTS OUT THROUGH THE DOORS PAP (quietly) That Rocklin'll kill him for sure.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ON PAP FOSSLER AND THE OTHERS AT WINDOW

dialogue.raw_text: Le's hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As George Clews steps outside, a mangy mongrel dog, basking close by, evidently recognizes him and tails it away, leaving George blinking at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin -- FROM George's ANGLE. He is walking slowly forward down the middle of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George, looking baffled by the steady approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He steps down from the sidewalk into the street and then stands still again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (yelling) I'm coming -- and you'd better run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rocklin -- CAMERA MOVING WITH him as he comes slowly and steadily forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George. His hands are on his guns, but drunk or not, he has too much sense to draw too soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- Harolday watching from behind the window of his office. Behind Harolday are Julio and Arly. The latter makes a step as if about to move to the door, but Julio restrains her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT -- as Garvey, Miss Martin and Clara watch the scene below -- Garvey and Miss Martin excitedly and Clara in great distress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- men in hotel doorway, taut with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin -- SHOOTING PAST George, whose hands are on his gun butts. Rocklin's thumbs are hooked in his belt as he continues slowly forward, his eyes fixed on George's.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Draw a gun and I'll kill you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: George, as he stands bewildered and open- mouthed. Rocklin enters scene, suddenly whips out his gun and brings it crashing down alongside George's head. The barrel strikes though the crown of his hat and he goes down like a pole- axed steer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT -- group at window. Arly gives an involuntary exclamation of pleasure, which she instantly checks, then she moves abruptly out of shot, followed by Juan. Harolday continues to stare frowningly out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT -- group at window, with Garvey obviously disapponted, Miss Martin bridling and Clara showing obvious relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- Rocklin and crowd as they swirl around him offering congratulations. Dave pushes his way through the crowd and thumps Rocklin on the back in wild enthusiasm. At the same time, the sound of a horse cantering is heard, and Jackson comes into shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns contemptuously and begins to move back towards the stage office completely ignoring Jackson, who rides alongside blusteringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd which has been following now begins to razz him openly. He turns and glares, but without effect. He gives a final shout to Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulling his horse around, he sets off in a lope up the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Rocklin) Hey, you! What's this you been up to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just laid a gun barrel over the head of a drunk friend of yours -- same as you did over Dave's here yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) Eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blustering) I don't know what you're talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) You're a liar!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you lookee here, young feller. You go on talking that way and you'll find yourself in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't say you ain't been warned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Miss Martin comes along the street, determinedly, followed by Clara, until she is face to face with Rocklin outside the stage office where Arly and Juan are mounted ready to move off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara pulls her sleeve imploringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes Clara by the arm and sweeps past them towards the hotel. Rocklin looks after them with a grim expression and then up at Arly, who has been listening intently. She returns his look steadily for a second. Then, with a mocking smile, she wheels the mare and canters out of shot, followed by Juan. He looks after her for a second; then with the same grim look, enters Harolday's office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring everyone but Rocklin) I saw you. I saw you strike that poor man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. As hard as I could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ruffian, you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me go! (to Rocklin) I knew the sort you were the moment I set eyes on you. You can't fool me! You're nothing but a common adventurer! Come, Clara!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Harolday is standing at the window, looking toward the door, having seen Rocklin approaching. The door opens and Rocklin enters and resumes his conversation as though it were hardly interrupted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin realizes that maybe Harolday is trying to throw a curve -- trying to get him to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET - SANTA INEZ - DAY On Dave and Pap Fossler engaged in conversation in front of Pap's store. In the b.g. -- across the street, we carry the entrance to the Sun-Up Saloon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During Dave's speech Rocklin has come from the Sun-up carrying his valise. He pauses a moment, looking around. Dave sees him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurries across the street toward Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now what was that you were sayin' about Caldwell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You being hired by Red Caldwell only confirms what I'd suspected -- he was getting ready to fight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to get information) Fight? Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Organized rustling. Well at least -- that's my belief. Red was no friend of mine. Too fond of taking the law into his own hands. But he had my sympathy. He'd been harder hit than any of us. And on top of it all, he lost his foreman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean, he quit on him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was shot -- in the back -- with a bullet from the same caliber rifle as got Red.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got any ideas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- Except that the man you just pistol-whipped is in on it somewhere. (bitterly) Pity you didn't kill him when you had the chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say -- it don't sound as if it's goin' to be too easy for them wimmen at the K.C.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching him keenly) Want to go back and work for them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir. And I ain't jumping at this offer o' yours either because I don't hold with working for wimmen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Oh, you mean my step-daughter. Well don't worry. She won't interfere with you...Rocklin -- I figure we've been losin' cattle over a place called Table Top -- it's the back way into the Topaz Ranch and the perfect route for rustlers -- I'm going to send you up to the line camp -- you don't mind working a lone hand -- do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (measuring)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like workin' that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising and holding out a hand) Good -- be ready to move out this afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in his best sales talk)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: now Pap -- I'm givin' you first call on me services. They's lots of other folks lookin' fer a good man, too -- you know. So if you want me, you better hurry and speak up because --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'scuse me, Pap -- Be right back to find out when I start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On Rocklin just stepping off the curb. Dave comes in to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start across the street, slowly toward the stage office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin gives Dave a quizzical look, which Dave mistakes for weakening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave and Rocklin have reached middle of the street. Pap Fossler's voice comes again from o.s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave reacts with a squint in Pap's direction. He runs out toward Pap, but would rather stay with Rocklin. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS Rocklin ACROSS the street To the stage office, where see Arly and Tala sitting on their horses apparently waiting for Rocklin. A third horse is standing by with Rocklin's saddle on it. Rocklin, upon reaching the front of the stage office, pauses a moment, to look over the horse carrying his saddle -- glances up to Arly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes into the stage of office, as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FORKED ROAD - DAY LONG SHOT -- as Rocklin, Arly and Juan canter along a dirt road over open country with the mountain ranges in the distance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Whar you off to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm riding for the Topaz Ranch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What! -- Have you gone plumb loco?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good money -- sixty a month
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There ain't enough money in this town to make it worth your while to work for that gal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When she gits goin' she can be meaner'n a skillet full o' snakes. She ain't goin' to forget the way you made a fool of her today -- in front of the whole town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hey, Dave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be right with you. (to Rocklin) It's pizen that's what it is -- jus' plain --- What you want to hang around this town for anyways? --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Dave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be right with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S to show a buggy on the road ahead, approaching a wooded dell where the road divides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT of the buggy, showing Miss Martin riding in front, beside Shorty Davis, who is driving, and Clara with her back to the driver, facing the oncoming trio. Miss Martin hears the sound of the approaching horses, and looks over her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly, Juan and Rocklin, with Miss Martin in F.g. The latter scowls and looks quickly to her front as the riders draw level with the buggy, Rocklin coining to the right, alongside Clara.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good afternoon, Mr. Rocklin. (looking at the sky) Lovely day, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reckon it is pretty nice. So you're moving in on the "K.C." eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitating and throwing a look toward Miss Martin) We-el, not exactly moving in. You see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with Miss Martin in f.g. and SHOOTING OVER her shoulder to include Clara and Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin looks quickly in the same direction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (acidly, locking straight ahead) Do you have to discuss our private affairs with every rag-tag-and-bobtail cow-person we meet, Clara?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a low voice) Auntie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry if I butted in, ma'am. Jest passing the time o'day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can do very well without it -- thank you. (with a look over her shoulder) And you're keeping your lady friend waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: from Rocklin's ANGLE, with Arly and Juan at the fork in the road. They are looking back towards the buggy which has taken the lower road to the right of the copse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with Arly and Juan in f.g. and the buggy in the distance. Rocklin raises his hat to the women in the buggy and canters back to Arly, who has been watching with a peculiar expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him angrily for a second as if about to say something sarcastic. Then, repressing herself, she wheels her horse and canters off along the side of the copse. Rocklin throws an amused glance, at Juan, who has been watching with an enigmatic expression. He returns Rocklin's look with a stern, menacing frown. Then, with a gentle flick of the rein, he urges his horse after Arly. Completely baffled, Rocklin scratches his head for a second, then follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RANCH HOUSE - SANTEE RANCH - LATE AFTERNOON MED. SHOT -- as the three canter up the driveway to a smart- looking ranch house. Arly dismounts and throws her reins to Juan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Rocklin can speak, she runs quickly up the steps of the verandah and disappears into the house. Leading Arly's Horse, Juan moves out of shot to the left of the ranch house and Rocklin follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) I thought maybe you'd changed your mind again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cheerfully) Nope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over her shoulder to Rocklin) Juan'll show you the bunkhouse. I'll talk to you about your duties in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- as Juan comes into shot leading the mare, followed by Rocklin. They both dismount and begin to off- saddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a moment's pause. Then, what almost amounts to a smile of relief, crosses Juan's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SANTEE RANCH - DAY LONG SHOT -- as Rocklin and Juan ride out from the ranch through the early morning mist and turn off in the direction of the distant line of mountains. DISSOLVE EXT. ENTRANCE TO CANYON - DAY LONG SHOT -- as the two leave the open country and enter the mouth of a steep and narrow gorge at the foot of the mountain range.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How far is the line-camp at Table- Top?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty-five -- thirty mile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm moving out there first thing in the morning. (as Juan turns and stares) Boss' orders. Care to show me the way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT as Juan pulls up and dismounts, followed by Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a second Juan does not reply. Then, as he speaks, he takes a tobacco pouch from his pocket. Rocklin, his mind on other things, does not take particular notice of the pouch, but we cannot help notice the pouch ornament -- a steer's head of hammered silver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin shakes his head. Juan, having spilled tobacco in a paper, now puts away the pouch and rolls his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns abruptly and mounts the waiting horse; then looks down from the saddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rides quickly out of the shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TABLE-TOP - DAY MED. SHOT -- as Rocklin forces his horse up the last few feet of the steep trail at the top of the canyon, and pulls up at the top of the rise with a look of amazement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing ahead) The trail is straight ahead. You will find the cabin at the top. (turning back to his horse) Adios, Senor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (challenging, but perfectly friendly) Senor Romerez, it appears that you do not like me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (during the above business) Senor, that is true. I do not like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (extending the pouch) Permit that I offer you a cigarette.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is not your fault that your shadow is black. But you will only bring unhappiness to my senorita. I do not blame you, but I fear I must hate you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Adios, Senor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A rich meadow stretches ahead with a stream running through it, and a cabin at the far end. Steep escarpments surround the lush meadow land, making an idyllic scene. As Rocklin comes slowly into shot with the same look of startled appreciation on his face and begins to move toward the cabin,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . APPROACH TO SANTEE RANCH - DAY LONG SHOT -- of Juan, as he canters across open country toward the ranch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S to include the road from Santa Inez along which approaches a smallish freight wagon, pulled by two horses. As the driver sees Juan and waves his whip, the Mexican swerves from his course and canters toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wagon, which we now see is being driven by Dave. On the side of the wagon is written: TRANSPORT & GENERAL FREIGHTAGE -- Pap Fossler and Sons. Juan canters into shot and pulls up alongside the wagon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hiya there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Buenos dias, Senor Dave. (looking at name on wagon) You have found new employer, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Haulin' freight for ole Pap Fossler. Got a letter here for that crazy galoot, Rocklin. (with a little Wink) From the little Caldwell girl. Seems mighty took up about sumpin'. Made me promise to deliver it personal. (indicates letter)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Senor Rocklin is not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lordy -- he ain't quit already...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) I have just accompany him to Table- Top.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TOPAZ RANCH HOUSE - DAY Shelley, a Negro servant of the Harolday household, is discovered sweeping the front porch. Behind him we see Clint open the door -- peer furtively out -- then cross the porch to its edge when he looks o.s. as though searching for someone. Shelley, meantime, has noticed Clint, but goes right on with his sweeping. His only reaction is a disparaging glance over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To emphasize his point, Shelley puckers his mouth in a whistle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clint's face tightens as he anticipates what is in store for him. Over the scene comes the gradually increasing sound of a feminine voice, gayly humming the notes of a popular tune of the period. Clint's strained features relax in a can-that- be-Arly expression, while Shelley stops dead in the middle of a sweep, and now both stare incredulously, o.s.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to Shelley) Have you seen Arly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, suh, Ah didn't see Miss Arly today, but Ah seed her las' night, and she shore was mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plenty mad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: From their ANGLE we first see only the corner of the house, while the owner of the voice approaches from the other side. Now Arly comes into view, entirely oblivious of Clint and Shelley watching her. She seems more attractive, in a feminine way, this morning. It may be the skirt and blouse she is wearing. Then again it may be the flower she is, even now, adjusting in her hair. The presence of the two men suddenly startles her. The song ends abruptly, while her hands fall quickly away from the flower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Arly moves toward the porch, Shelley snaps back to life and resumes sweeping -- but furiously. Clint regards the girl in the vague manner of the puzzled gent he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly is coming toward Clint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She steps close to Clint, and he slowly backs up a step, for he does not know she came up to him merely to pick up her jacket lying on the ground near the step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly straightens up with the jacket in her hand, and the corner of her mouth curls in a faint smile. She turns now and starts along the walk, and takes only a few steps when Clint comes to her side.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (not too definitely) 'Mornin', Arly --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) 'Mornin', Clint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Arly leans down to pick up the jacket) You must be feeling pretty good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (as he joins Arly) Say, Arly -- about that poker game, night before last, I --- ARLY (tossing it off) Forget it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly pays no attention to Clint. She is looking o.s. and stops walking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (did he hear correctly) Forget it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tala, on his horse, as seen by Arly. Over the scene comes Arly's voice calling from a distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tala reacts to the call by heading his horse at a slightly different angle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Tala.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Arly is looking o.s. toward Tala. Clint is now eyeing his sister up and down quite openly. She turns her head now and catches Clint looking her over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gesture of his hand indicates the way Arly has gotten herself up. That quick, Arly's hand goes to the flower in her hair. And, that quick, she guiltily withdraws it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before he can explain, Tala pulls up in his horse and we hear his voice over the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (after a stilted pause) Well -- CLINT (with a perplexed smile) What is this? --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bravely nonchalant) What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do I mean? --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Arliete.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tala sitting astride his horse smiles down at the girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly is jolted by Tala's innocent remark, and she can't help giving Clint a little side glance in the way of reaction. Clint has not missed Tala's crack nor Arly's glance, and when she gives it to him he says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses her an altogether knowing look now, and leaves, going up the walk toward the house. Arly turns to Tala.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances over her shoulder toward Clint going up the walk. And then, looking back to Tala, finds he hasn't moved, but remains smiling down at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly looks away. Her eyes stare blankly into space as she struggles with the mixed emotions of anger and disappointment. Tala, aware of her plight, slowly dismounts and comes to the girl's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly is quiet a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good morning, Tala.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have make yourself very pretty today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) See what I mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have my horse saddled and sent around right away -- will you? (then as a casual afterthought) You can have that Rocklin bring it.

His hat is tipped back on his head, and his sleeves are rolled up. He is mixing dough in a bowl sitting on the table near the letter, and his hands are all gooey. Dave is discovered in front of the fireplace where his outer shirt and socks are drying. It is dark outside, but the storm has abated. Rocklin goes to a shelf near the fireplace to get a pan.

Dave, seeing this, edges discreetly around in back of Rocklin in order to see over his shoulder. The letter open, Rocklin takes out a roll of bills along with the folded message. direction.raw_text: . OF CABIN - NIGHT Rocklin has reached the entrance unheard, and silently watches the strange figure, its back to him, now headed for the fireplace with his saddlebag, taken from the bunk. He sees the intruder start emptying his saddlebag on the bench in the light of the fire. He sees him suddenly stop and pick up something hidden from his view. At that instant, Rocklin slams the door shut. The intruder whirls around. It is Arly -- tense -- and now defiant. The two regard each other like vicious animals in the same cage. Arly's heart is pounding, but you would never know it. And now Rocklin, his gun away, starts closing in, slowly -- but Arly holds her ground -- her eyes never leaving his. When Rocklin reaches Arly, he takes her one hand from behind her back, and slowly forcing it up sees what is obviously Clara's letter in her tightly clenched fist. He tries to open her hand, and Arly, knowing she lacks the strength to prevent it, suddenly whips out a knife with her free hand. But that quick, Rocklin grabs the knife hand, and without any apparent effort, wrenches it free of her grasp and tosses it across the room, where it lands on the bunk. Arly relaxes her grip on the letter meanwhile, and Rocklin gets it, and tears it very deliberately, letting the pieces fall at her feet. He turns his back on her now, going over to his hat on the floor. Arly is furious in her helplessness and humiliation. And Rocklin's smug manner isn't helping any. He picks up his hat and, glancing at Arly, puts his finger once more through the bullet holes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin puts his hat on. He sees Arly looking down at the torn letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin goes toward the bunk with his saddlebag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin sits on the bunk and casually picks up Arly's knife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That last from Arly brings a kind of smile to Rocklin's face -- a smile that says in effect -- "Are you kidding?" He gets up from the bunk to go to the door, and finding himself still holding Arly's knife, throws it back to her in a seemingly casual manner. It passes too close to Arly for comfort and, Rocklin just opening the door, gets the knife right back -- that close to his ear he feels the breeze. He looks at it, quivering in the door. Then, moving to Arly in what could be construed as a threatening manner, he takes her in his arms and kisses her. Arly is caught completely unaware. Rocklin's action disarms her. But it is, after all, what she really wants, so before the kiss ends, Arly's arms slowly entwine themselves around Rocklin's neck. In the middle of the kiss Rocklin gently but forcefully takes her arms from around his neck and puts her from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to the bunk -- picks up his saddlebag, coat, etc., and starts for the door. Arly has been silently watching.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Clint as he enters from street and crosses to the door of Harolday's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on door of inner office with Harolday at desk in f.g. As the door opens it conceals Rocklin from Clint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clint looks quickly at Harolday and back at Rocklin with frightened eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin makes no reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls out the tobacco pouch which Dave found at Table- Top.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) I just heard that -- that Rocklin was -- (sees Rocklin)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly) Was what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (subdued) Was shot at last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very calm) Mr. Rocklin was just telling me all about it. (significantly) Any idea who might have done it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't trying to pin it on me? (his courage returning) 'Cause if you are, you're in for a big disappointment. I was over at the Sun-Up playing poker with the Judge and the rest of the boys till early morning. If you don't believe me, ask for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) All right. I believe you. But that don't mean you couldn't tell a thing or two as would help -- if you wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very nervous again) What d'you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) Yes. What sort of thing would Clint here know about, that would help identify the man who tried to kill you last night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This for one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever seen it before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clint as he stares wide-eyed at the pouch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: group, with Rocklin and Harolday both watching Clint intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin's disdainful smile takes the speech out of Clint, who just sort of runs out of words. Rocklin hesitates for a second then moves toward the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (harshly) Well, go on -- speak up. Did you ever see it before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (avoiding Harolday's eye) No. Course I didn't (suddenly raging at Rocklin) Quit riding me! I don't know nothin' about it I tell you. Jest because I had a run-in with you over a game o' cards, that don't mean I'd sneak up on you in the dark and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Harolday and Clint are at window looking past camera toward the street. They see Rocklin carrying his saddle, walking toward the Sun-Up. Shorty Davis hails Rocklin, says something to him and points to the Sun-Up. Rocklin leaves, walking faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns from camera toward the desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (frowning deeply) He means trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still at window) Aw, what do I care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning on him with cold fury) Listen, I never did have much use for you. You're a poor specimen at the best; but as a would-be bad man you're nothing but a laughing stock. Why, the way you lied about that pouch just now wouldn't have deceived a six-year old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (harshly) All right, let it go at that. But I got myself to think of. It wouldn't suit me at all just now to have you shown up in public for what you are by that trouble-shootin' cowhand. My advice to you is to get out of the district and stay out. (taking a key from his vest pocket) You'll find some money in the safe at the ranch. Take what you need and put the key in the desk drawer. Now get.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rocklin comes down the hall carrying his saddle and looking at the room numbers. As he nears the f.g. he locates the room he is looking for (it is a room facing toward the rear of the Sun-Up). He knocks. Almost immediately the door opens and Clara stands there -- flushed and embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. ROCKLIN'S ROOM - SUN-UP SALOON - DAY This is the room in which Clara has arranged to meet Rocklin, who later takes it as his own.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Rocklin --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: at door as Rocklin steps into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin notes her confusion. He regards her with a slight sympathetic smile. Then opens the door and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARVEY'S OFFICE - DAY CLOSE SHOT -- a letter written in a bold feminine hand. It reads:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so glad I've found you -- I was on my way to the Santee and learned you were in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting his saddle, etc., aside) Just got in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel perfectly awful, running after you like this, but -- ROCKLIN You got trouble, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My aunt found out I wrote you and made a terrible scene -- ROCKLIN You haven't signed everything over to that Garvey, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- and because I refused, Auntie said she would sign an affidavit that I'm still underage, and then, as my guardian she can do what she likes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got anything to prove you're not underage?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a slight pause) No -- but Mr. Garvey has a letter that would prove it. My aunt wrote it before we came out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: S'pose we could get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'd never give it to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starts for door) Wait here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a slight start toward Rocklin) Oh, please -- you -- (she hesitates, not quite sure what to say) You won't go getting yourself in trouble -- I -- I'd rather give up everything -- I mean --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GARVEY: In answer to your letter of the 25th, kindly be advised that my niece, Clara Caldwell, became of age January 11th of this year. And, although I am no longer her legal guardian, it behooves me, as her nearest kin, to show continued interest in her affairs -- The CAMERA HOLDS LONG ENOUGH for the letter to be read. And now the letter begins to be consumed in a flame as the CAMERA PULLS BACK showing the burning letter in Judge Garvey's hand. He is standing over the potbellied stove in his office, and Miss Martin is close to him watching the letter burn. Garvey finally lets it fall from his fingers onto the top of the stove. He lifts the lid, lets the remains fall inside, and smiles to Miss Martin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Rocklin enters. Miss Martin, who has been pacing nervously, stops in her tracks. Garvey, taken completely by surprise, feigns an affected casualness. Rocklin eyes them both suspiciously as he slowly closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is quite obvious to Garvey that Rocklin is here on business. He turns to Miss Martin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Martin is in accord with that suggestion, and after giving Rocklin the frigid eye, flounces out, slamming the door. Garvey shakes his head, wipes his brow, and is returning to his desk.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That takes care of that -- (crosses to his desk) Now, I'll draw up an affidavit right away and everything will be taken care of as we want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not too enthusiastic) I certainly hope so -- it's not myself I'm concerned about -- GARVEY (getting out the papers)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't say I'm very happy about doing this -- I only hope it works out for the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the better choice of two evils -- now let's see -- (begins to write)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth -- (looks at Miss Martin) It is Elizabeth, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- GARVEY -- Elizabeth Martin, of Danvers, Massachusetts, do hereby --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaning back in his chair) Well, Mr. Rocklin, this is indeed a surprise. Didn't expect to see you so soon. I understood you were riding for the Santee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Miss Martin) Perhaps you'd better come back later --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- door to Garvey's office. Miss Martin has her ear glued to the panels. Over scene comes Rocklin's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Martin reacts.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I came for that letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- Garvey and Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Did you say letter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right -- the one Miss Caldwell's aunt wrote from out east sayin' she was of age. Remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I'm afraid I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- door. Miss Martin reacts with nod of satisfaction and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin goes to the filing cabinet where he opens the drawer marked "C." As he fingers through the papers, Garvey sits back in his chair, watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin pulls open the "M" drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not finding the letter in the "M" drawer, Rocklin goes to the desk and pulls the handle of one of the drawers. It is locked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Garvey unlocks the drawer and opens it. It is found to contain nothing but two brand new decks of playing cards. The UNOPENED DECKS OF CARDS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is your interest in this letter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My only interest is getting' it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You realize what this is, don't you? -- Robbing -- armed robbery at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I warn you, you're in for a disappointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (has had about enough) Listens, you -- (suddenly controls himself) There's nothing in there that'd interest you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) I'd like to make up my own mind about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (forces a chuckle) All right -- I'll open it -- just to convince you I'm not hiding any letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Garvey seems a little too anxious to close the drawer, and before he can do so, Rocklin has one hand inside. Garvey, checked for a second, looks up at Rocklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin slowly withdraws his hand, holding one of the decks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two regard each other silently a moment. Now Rocklin casually slips the deck he holds into his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a step away. Garvey turns him by touching his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts around the desk toward the door. From the corner of his eye he catches Garvey reaching for a gun in the middle drawer. Before he can raise it, Rocklin is on him with a blow that sends Garvey reeling back toward the stove. Rocklin starts for the door again, and just misses being struck by a chair which Garvey hurls with vicious fury. The chair crashes against a window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's the idea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These cards -- GARVEY (attempting to bluff it out) Anything wrong in a man having cards in his possession?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends on what kind they are -- 'specially when they're under lock and key.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (too politely) You're taking those, I presume.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (has had almost enough) Now, you look here -- ROCKLIN (soberly) You're the one who better start lookin' -- lookin' for a way out for killin' Red Caldwell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blanches) Caldwell -- ROCKLIN (takes up one of the decks of cards) He found out about these -- and you went and killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with an affected smile and unnatural calmness) And you believe a story like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will until I hear a better one. (puts deck he holds, in his pocket) I'll just take this along -- the district judge at Garden City should be mighty interested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The sound of breaking glass attracts the attention of passers- by, as well as Miss Martin seated in her surrey with Sammy, the K.C. China-boy.
direction.name: direction

location: STREET IN FRONT OF GARVEY'S OFFICE
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: The two are now fighting in earnest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the fight, intercut with townspeople gathering outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave pulls up in his wagon.
direction.name: direction

location: STREET IN FRONT OF GARVEY'S OFFICE
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: It is pretty well wrecked. Rocklin has Garvey just about done in. He gives him one final Sunday punch and Garvey goes down and stays down. At that moment, Dave and Pap Fossler enter followed by other curious natives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They exit, and almost immediately Miss Martin enters, and after gaping in horror at the appearance of the place, sees the Judge, who, having regained consciousness, bestirs himself on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Garvey, on his feet now, makes for the door leading to his living quarters at the back of the office. Miss Martin follows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sees the bed and shrieks upon realizing where she is, and backs out quickly, almost catching the door which Garvey slams in her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Say -- looks like you two been disagreein' 'bout somethin' -- (to Fossler, who has gone over to Garvey) He ain't daid, is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not permanently, I don't reckon. -- What happened, anyways?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Rocklin) You musta found out somethin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with a wink to Dave) I reckon the Judge did, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, dear -- dear -- are you hurt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up painfully) Get out of my way --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (haughtily) Now don't you use that tone of voice to me -- (going through doorway) I'll have you understand I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rocklin and Dave as they walk from Garvey's office. Dave has a time hopping along against Rocklin's strides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave leaves and exits from shot in the direction of the stage office. Rocklin goes off toward the Sun-Up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Find out who owns that tobaccy pouch yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring straight ahead) No -- but get hold of Clint Harolday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clint -- Is he in on it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't say for sure -- Bring him to the Sun-Up, and don't take no for an answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Juan is lounging against the corner of the building, soberly watching Rocklin's approach. As Rocklin comes into the scene he spots Juan, and stops a moment as though deciding whether or not to question him. During this, Juan casually takes his ornamental tobacco pouch from his pocket and begins to roll a cigarette. The CAMERA PANS Rocklin to the side of the building and up the outer stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin comes through the door and down the hall. He reaches his room, and is about to open the door when he hears a familiar voice inside. He listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin frowns and enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So now you know the truth. And if you think you can steal him away from me, you're welcome to try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rocklin steps into the room, holding the door partly open as he focuses his attention on Arly. Clara, who has been sitting in the rocker near the window, gets up and is the first to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara is terribly hurt, but struggles to be grown-up about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara can say no more without breaking. So she turns away quickly and hurries out the door. Rocklin does a slow burn as he glares at Arly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin makes no reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arly is being ridiculous now. He ignores her remarks and concentrates his attention on one of his hands -- he may have sprained it slightly in the fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a folded piece of paper out of her pocket and drops it on the dresser as Rocklin watches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door closes. Rocklin stands a moment. Now curiosity brings him to the dresser where he takes up the paper and unfolds it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (anxiously) Did you get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- but I don't think it's gonna matter much -- you go on back to the K.C. and I'll be out in the mornin' and take you with me to Garden City to see the district judge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I hate putting you to that trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No trouble at all -- I'm going anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (casually) You look like you've been fighting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soberly) What are you doin' here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just telling Miss Caldwell about -- well -- you and me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his eyes narrowing) What about, you an' me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sensing the static in the atmosphere) I think I'd better be going...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning quickly from Arly) Just a minute -- (glances at Arly) What all has she been tellin' you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (embarrassed) Oh -- oh, really I'd rather not -- ARLY (interrupting) Go ahead, tell him -- (looks at Rocklin and goes on defiantly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and I dare him to deny it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deny what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That she was with you last night at the cabin in the mountains.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- why should I deny it?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) And didn't you make love to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (this is getting a bit thick for him) Make love to you -- ARLY (forcing her point) You didn't kiss me -- I suppose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you expect me to deny that, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles at Clara) You see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Clara) Now, maybe you ought to hear what I've got to say --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please -- you needn't explain. After all, it really isn't any of my business, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in the pause he looks at Arly) You little -- ARLY (quickly) That's it -- start swearin'-- (to Clara) Just like a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If there wasn't a lady here, I'd do more to you than swear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how I can ever thank you for trying to help me. I do appreciate it ever so much -- (to Arly) Don't think too harshly of me, will you -- I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sincerely -- after a pause) She's lovely, isn't she? -- So sweet -- honest, and helpless.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pity you didn't fall in love with her, instead of me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You might's well know right now that you or no woman is ever goin' to get me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be so sure -- I don't think I'm doin' so badly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know there ain't a dirty trick you wouldn't play to get what you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I always get what I want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See? (opens the door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Bye now --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . The torn pieces have all been sorted and pasted together on a sheet of paper
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Rocklin holds the letter. He is mad. He shakes his head -- What a gal --- Now he is almost smiling -- almost. He folds the letter -- puts it in his pocket. Takes off his gun-belt and hangs it over the rocker near the window, and stretches out on the bed, as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CALDWELL HOUSE - LATE AFTERNOON ON Clara hurrying toward the front door in a suppressed state of excitement. She has presumably just arrived at the ranch in advance of Miss Martin. She enters the house after a glance toward the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara enters hastily and beats a path to the door of her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door flies open. Clara bursts in, closing the door in the same movement. Her eyes swing to someone o.s. and she freezes to the spot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Martin, standing by the window, cold and threatening. She has not taken the time to remove her hat. After a moment's pause, she moves slowly toward Clara. The CAMERA PANS WITH her into a TWO SHOT. Clara, her back pressing harder and harder against the door, becomes more terrified at the other's approach. Miss Martin appraises the girl a short moment and now suddenly slaps her hard across the face. Clara opens her mouth, about to scream, but even stifles this impulse under the cold stare of her aunt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara can only stare as one under an hypnotic spell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara hasn't moved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara merely gasps for a breath of air, but Miss Martin, thinking her about to speak, goes on, more forcefully now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara remains silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clara, now utterly broken, moves away. Miss Martin, her eyes still rivited on the girl, follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARVEY'S OFFICE - LATE AFTERNOON The office has been more or less cleaned up since the fight. Garvey is discovered near the window. He has cleaned himself up but bears some evidence of the fight. He is reading a letter as Sammy, the K.C. China-boy, stands waiting near the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly but viciously) Whatever is to become of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you no sense of pride, or decency? Throwing yourself at that -- that wretch, like any shameless hussy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we'd done with him -- but no -- you have to run to him and tell him all our business --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you dare deny it -- you know very well you told him about that letter I wrote Mr. Garvey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you? --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . The message is written in the same bold hand of Miss Martin already seen in the previous letter: Mr. Garvey, I have just learned that despicable Rocklin person intends to take Clara to Garden City in the morning -- evidently to have you investigated. I thought you had better know about it. E.M.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Garvey puts the message in his pocket as he addresses Sammy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROCKLIN'S ROOM - NIGHT On Rocklin, stretched across the bed, examining the cards in the light of a lamp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Miss Martin that I'll take care of everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You take clare of evelything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Garvey comes from around the building's corner and peers furtively through the darkness toward the lighted windows of Rocklin's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The area in front of the Sun-Up. Dave's wagon pulls up to the hitching rail in front of the saloon. Clint, stripped of his gun, is driving with Dave, alertly watching him. They get down from the wagon and Dave prods Clint toward the corner of the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Garvey has left the spot where we saw him look up to Rocklin's window. We now see him as he rounds a rear corner of the building and goes toward the outer stairs leading to the Sun- Up's second floor. He starts up the steps and stops almost immediately and stares o.s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From Garvey's ANGLE as he sees Dave bringing Clint from around in front of the building toward the stairway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Garvey steps quickly to the ground and takes up a position around the roar corner. He watches the two men approach the stairway and go up. He moves out of the shot now, going toward the street. The CAMERA HOLDS on the corner, and we see Tala come into view, as though from nowhere, and take the exact position at the building's corner vacated by Garvey only a moment before. It is apparent that he is watching Garvey, and after a momentary pause he too moves stealthily out of the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Rocklin asleep. He is fully dressed, as we last saw him, with the exception of his boots. He is stretched full length on top of the covers. His gun-belt still hangs over the rocker, close to the open window. A knock on the door brings him to a sitting position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CAMERA PANS TO door as Clint enters reluctantly, followed by the triumphant Dave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses Dave a coin, who catches it. Then Rocklin puts on his boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dave exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rocklin begins rolling a cigarette as he moves toward Clint.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come in --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here he is, Rock. Caught him jist in time near the Santee. Headed fer out, I'd say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down, Clint. (to Dave, as he reaches into his pocket) How about goin' down below an' havin' one on me?
dialogue.name: dialogue
